sect1.title: About DACS and the DACS Java Library
sect1.para: DACS is a collection of software components that manages identities throughout a federation of distributed systems and enforces role-based access control, providing single sign-on functionality.

DACS is designed to be a general-purpose authentication and access control framework, suitable for a wide variety of environments and applications. DACS is commonly used in the context of web services, and in conjunction with the Apache web server, where web services are typically invoked by people using off-the-shelf web browsers as their user agent. DACS may be used to secure a single web server or as a full-fledged single sign-on and federated identity solution.

The &DJL; (DJL) is being developed to support the use of DACS in Java client applications. Support is provided in several key areas:
establishing the necessary preconditions for access
hiding implementation details of DACS Web services (HTTP request signatures, XML reply parsing, etc)
specialization of the excellent
Jakarta Commons HttpClient
library for DACS request processing

The DJL may be used in the development of Java applications deployed in thick-client (typically Java Swing) and
middleware

An example application of DJL in a user agent configuration is the User-friendly Desktop Internet GIS application, uDig, which uses the DJL to incorporate DACS authentication and notice acknowledgement that has been configured in front of
Open Geospatial Consortium
Web map servers. The DACS Federation Administration Web application, FedAdmin (also released on the SourceForge dacs-contrib project), is an example middleware application which uses the DJL not only for authentication but to invoke DACS web services for the administration of one or more DACS federations and their member jurisdictions.
